item.title: Syrian Asylum Seeker Linked to Mass Execution Is Arrested in Sweden
item.description: A man who sought asylum in Sweden is believed to be among a group of Syrian rebels who were recorded executing seven soldiers in 2012.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: C. J. CHIVERS

item.title: Putin Said to Order Start of Withdrawal From Syria
item.description: The order from the Kremlin came as the United Nations has sought to resume peace talks to end the war, entering its sixth year.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: A curtain hung to protect pedestrians from the view of snipers in a rebel-held suburb of Damascus on Sunday.

item.title: Israel Calls on U.N. to Punish Iran for Missile Tests
item.description: The Israeli ambassador to the United Nations accused Iran of violating the nuclear accord by testing missiles capable of reaching Israel last week.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:credit: Omid Vahabzadeh/Fars News Agency, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A photograph obtained from the Fars news agency in Iran showed a long-range missile that was said to be fired in Iran last week.

item.title: American Fighting With ISIS Captured in Iraq
item.description: The American man left Virginia to fight for the Islamic State and was caught near the northern city of Sinjar, Kurdish and U.S. officials said.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: KAMIL KAKOL
item.media:description: A photograph posted on social media by a Kurdish fighter shows a man the Kurdish military says is an American member of the Islamic State. It was taken on Monday, shortly after he turned himself in to Kurdish fighters in northern Iraq.

item.title: Turkey ‘Almost Certain’ that Kurdish Militants Bombed Ankara, Premier Says
item.description: The government’s blaming the Kurdistan Workers’ Party, or P.K.K., could raise tensions between Turkey and the United States, who are allies in Syria.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU and TIM ARANGO
item.media:description: A Turkish forensic team on Monday investigates the site of deadly bombing in Ankara, the Turkish capital, which killed 37 people on Sunday.

item.title: Trilobites: This Week Surfers Will Ride a Wave in the Amazon
item.description: The Pororoca, a tidal bore, tumbles in from the ocean and travels up the river on a path of destruction. But surfers love it.
item.dc:creator: JOANNA KLEIN
item.media:description: People surf on the wave of a tidal bore known as “Pororoca” in March 2015 during an annual festival in Sao Domingos do Capim, Brazil.

item.title: Warplane Crashes in Yemen Amid Fight Against Houthis
item.description: Two pilots were killed when the United Arab Emirates plan went down. A Saudi news agency cited a “technical malfunction.”
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:description: An armored vehicle operated by the Saudi-led coalition searched for the wreckage of a fighter jet from the United Arab Emirates that crashed in the southern port city of Aden, Yemen, on Monday.

item.title: Hillary Clinton’s Deep Ties to Haiti Show Signs of Strain
item.description: Although Mrs. Clinton’s most notable involvement with the country included emergency relief, some Haitian-Americans think she did more harm than good.
item.dc:creator: YAMICHE ALCINDOR
item.media:description: Protesters demonstrated against Hillary Clinton in Port-au-Prince during her visit there as secretary of state in January 2011.

item.title: Witness Recalls Ivory Coast Attack: ‘Shooting, Then Boom, Boom, Boom’
item.description: Charline Burton, who works for a nonprofit, hid in a bathroom with her 1-year-old daughter as gunmen outside carried out a bloody rampage.
item.category: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY
item.media:description: Bodies were removed from a beach after a shooting rampage in Grand-Bassam, Ivory Coast, on Sunday.

item.title: Boston Journal: As More Immigrants Arrive, Some Britons Want to Show Them and E.U. the Door
item.description: Their presence has caused anxiety and resentment in Boston, a town in northeast England that has come to epitomize the country’s rising antagonism toward immigration.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Workers harvested vegetables this month in the fields around Boston, in northeast England.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Stop Your Backsliding, Europe
item.description: Humanitarian commitments made to refugees must not be abandoned now.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: NILS MUIZNIEKS

item.title: Labor Protests Multiply in China as Economy Slows, Worrying Leaders
item.description: Concerned about their prospects in a gloomy job market, workers are fighting back with unusual ferocity.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Workers having lunch at a restaurant near a factory for Angang Lianzhong in Guangzhou, China, last month.

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: The Trump-Berlusconi Syndrome
item.description: Lessons from Italy on the rise of a showman in a time of anxiety.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Can Israel Handle a President Trump?
item.description: After eight years of Obama, Israel’s prime minister thought he wanted a Republican president. Then came the primaries.
item.dc:creator: SHMUEL ROSNER

item.title: In China, a Surge in Strikes
item.description: A downturn in the economy has caused a boom in worker demonstrations and strikes across China. One man is trying to help those who are most vulnerable in China’s slowing economy.

item.title: One-Third of Syrian Children Were Born During War, Unicef Report Finds
item.description: More than 300,000 in this group were born as refugees, according to a report by the United Nations Children’s Fund.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:credit: Save the Children, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Two children walked through the corridors of a destroyed school last November in Eastern Ghouta, Syria. A United Nations report found that 80 percent of the country’s youth are in urgent need of humanitarian aid because of the conflict.

item.title: Sinosphere: Xi Jinping Brought Down a Notch by an Unlikely Agent: A Typo
item.description: The use of one wrong character in a Xinhua article resulted in President Xi Jinping being called “China’s last leader,” rather than “China’s highest.”
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping at the opening session of the Chinese People’s Political Consultative Conference in Beijing.

item.title: Sinosphere: Officials in China Call for National Standards on Halal Food
item.description: Some of China’s more than 23 million Muslims worry that businesses routinely flout Islamic law.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ and ADAM WU
item.media:description: A waiter leaving the kitchen of a halal restaurant in Jiayuguan, in the northwestern Chinese province of Gansu.

item.title: Editorial: Mr. Netanyahu’s Lost Opportunities
item.description: It’s hard to understand how showing disrespect to the president of the United States serves Israel’s interests.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel last week at a cabinet meeting in Jerusalem.

item.title: Explosion in Ankara Kills at Least 34, Turkish Officials Say
item.description: The blast in Turkey’s capital, less than a month after a bombing on a military convoy in the city, was believed to have been caused by a car bomb.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.media:description: A blast in the heart of Ankara killing more than 30 was the latest in a string of attacks that have destabilized the country.
